awd_abstract_narration:
IIP 1140438 
North Carolina State University; Denis Gray 
IUCRC Evaluation Project 

The IUCRC program is comprised of over 50 centers with over 150 participating universities. These centers include over 750 industry members, 600 faculty scientists, 1000 graduate students and almost 250 undergraduate students. The current proposal requests support for a five-year award to support evaluation activities of the IUCRC Program. 

The proposed IUCRC Evaluation Project addresses both accountability and improvement evaluation issues and involves both program-level and center-level elements. The evaluation addresses three major objectives: 1) To help NSF and local centers objectively evaluate their impact by documenting IUCRC outcomes and accomplishments; 2) To promote continuous improvement by giving actionable, timely, data-based (formally collected and observational) feedback, analysis and advice to NSF and local centers; 3) To identify and communicate information about IUCRC best practices to NSF and local centers. Research and evaluation conducted through the IUCRC Evaluation Project in the past has made a significant contribution to a broadened understanding of cooperative research in general and industry/university centers in particular. The proposed work sets comparably ambitious goals and promises to make a contribution to the understanding of a variety of critical issues including the economic impact of IUCRCs, impact of IUCRCs on small firms, and human capital impacts of IUCRCs. 

The most unique characteristic of the IUCRC Evaluation Project is the emphasis placed on improvement evaluation for local center directors with timely evaluation data collected from key stakeholder groups. The project will be a training vehicle for the next generation of S&T evaluators by promoting high quality research opportunities for the graduate students supported by the project. Finally, the proposed work will continue to be very proactive in disseminating the findings to the broader scientific community by publishing the work in widely read and high quality journals. Further, all evaluation instruments, program reports, and student and faculty papers related to the program evaluation effort will be publicly available on the Program Evaluation Website housed on North Carolina State University servers (www.ncsu.edu/iucrc).
org_div_long_name: Division of Engineering Education and Centers

por.por_cntn:
Cooperative research centers (CRCs), like Industry/University Cooperative Research Centers (IUCRCs), are a growing and increasingly important part of the U.S. innovation ecosystem.  Since 1979, the NSF has launched 176 IUCRCs, with over 350 sites at nearly 150 universities, and an estimated 2200 member firms. The current project attempted to assist in the success of IUCRCs by collecting evaluation data that would contribute to achieving two objectives:  to contribute to an understanding of the operations and outcomes of IUCRCs and similar cooperative research schemes; to help improve center and program operations and performance by providing timely feedback of evaluation data on processes and outcomes. Data collected over the course of the project have helped identify operational best practices. For instance, IUCRCs that take a more consortial approach have better member retention.  Data collection also demonstrates center efficacy in terms of enhancing the education and career trajectory of students, leveraging federal funding, and improving member firm R&D efficacy, ultimately leading to some process or product launches that result in hundreds of millions of dollars in income or cost savings.  Over the last ten years, nearly 6000 degrees have been awarded to students trained in IUCRCs. Those students go on to pursue careers in industry, academia and government, with 27% being hired directly by member firms. For every dollar that NSF has invested in IUCRCs since 1985, those funds have been leveraged 1:9 against funds contributed to the centers from industry and other sources.  Impressively, for every $1 invested by the average center member, that member gets access to $44.75 worth of center research.  And over the last four years, center members have reported $889 Million in research cost avoidance and $226 Million in research cost savings.  Over the last five years, center research has stimulated $247 Million in follow-on research within member firms and has spawned over 25 spinoff companies. A targeted study on subsidized memberships for SBIR firms documented significant social capital, R&D and commercialization benefits for these firms.  At the same time, the project has pioneered a novel "improvement-focused evaluation" strategy wherein on-site evaluators use benchmarking data, documented best practices and feedback from various stakeholders to help improve IUCRC performance. Anecdotal evidence suggests these efforts have contributed to the high success rate achieved by IUCRCs.  Nearly two-thirds of centers that graduate from the IUCRC program are able to continue operating as self-sustaining centers, post-NSF funding.

 


Last Modified: 09/08/2016
Modified by: Denis O Gray
